G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 21, the Newton Division of the District Court Department has jurisdiction over this civil action, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of this Court and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 3.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 and 3, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court, and because Defendant resides in and/or may be found within this judicial district.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states as a general principle of Massachusetts tort law that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, and ties that duty to foreseeability of harm. While the case then applies that principle to a specific homeowner–firearms scenario, the court clearly adopts the broad common-law duty rule that aligns with the proposition. The discussion of foreseeability as a precondition refines, but does not contradict, the claimed general duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion recites the elements the plaintiffs must prove in a negligence action and cites the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281, but it does not discuss the existence or scope of a general duty of reasonable care owed by “every person” to avoid foreseeable harm. The court expressly declines to decide whether the defendant owed any duty at all, resolving the case solely on lack of causation. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the broad duty proposition asserted.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965)… Causation is an essential element of that proof.… Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them…”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty, but it does so in the specific context of landowner liability and control over adjacent public highways. It does not state any general Massachusetts common-law rule that "every person" owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. Instead, it frames duty as a question of law informed by social policy and then narrows its analysis to landowners and abutting highways; thus it is not proper authority for the broad, universal-duty proposition cited.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, *743and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. See O’Gorman v. Antonio Rubinaccio & Sons, 408 Mass. 758, 760 (1990); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989). Whether such a duty exists is a question of law. Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (1991), citing Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., supra. In determining whether the defendant had a duty to be careful, we look to existing social values and customs, as well as to appropriate social policy.

Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.raw_text: Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161–62 (1933)
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and keeper of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the control and supervision of the Dog, particularly in a public park frequented by joggers, pedestrians, and other members of the public.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case expressly notes there was no evidence that the defendant was the owner or keeper of the dog, and instead analyzes the defendant’s duty only as a storeowner to keep premises reasonably safe for customers. It also recites the common-law rule that even an owner or keeper of a dog is not liable absent knowledge of dangerous propensities, and ultimately holds there was no duty to exclude or restrain a dog with no known dangerous tendencies. Thus, it does not support the proposition that a dog’s owner/keeper generally owes a duty to exercise reasonable care in controlling the dog in a public place such as a park.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, and it is not contended, that the defendant or any of its agents or servants was the owner or keeper of the dog… The plaintiff can recover only upon proof of breach of the defendant’s duty to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer. … Apart from statute even an owner or keeper of a dog… is not liable for bodily injuries inflicted by it in the absence of proof that he knew, or at least should have known, its dangerous propensities….”

Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u20.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and keeper of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the control and supervision of the Dog, particularly in a public park frequented by joggers, pedestrians, and other members of the public.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u20.support_reasoning: The case concerns statutory strict liability of a dog’s owner or keeper under G.L. c. 140, § 155 and issues of pleading/ownership/keeping, not a common-law duty of reasonable care in controlling a dog. The opinion does not discuss negligence standards, public parks, or duties to joggers or pedestrians; it simply affirms that owners/keepers are liable under the statute once ownership/keeping is proven. Thus it does not support the proposition about a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervision and control of the dog in a public setting.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86, 89\u20.relevant_excerpt: G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: “The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.” … Here if Agostino and Rachele jointly were both owners and keepers of the dog, a liability would be established. … He was right in pointing out that the mere presence of the dog on the premises where defendants lived, or acquiescence in its presence, was not enough to show ownership or keeping, but that harboring with an assumption of custody, management and control of the dog was evidence of keeping….

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155\u2013157.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable state and local laws and regulations requiring that dogs in the Park be kept on a leash, including but not limited to G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–157 and any Newton ordinances adopting and enforcing leash requirements.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Breach of such statutes and ordinances is evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the effect of violating a statute like G.L. c. 138, § 69 on negligence liability. It expressly states that such a violation is not negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence. Thus, the case clearly supports the narrower proposition that breach of such statutes and ordinances is evidence (but not conclusive proof) of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.raw_text: Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499–501 (1968)
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.proposition: Breach of such statutes and ordinances is evidence of negligence.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the general rule that violation of a criminal statute constitutes some evidence of negligence as to the harms the statute was designed to prevent. That is precisely the proposition that breach of such statutes and ordinances is evidence (not conclusive proof) of negligence, and the court applies that principle to the alleged violation of G.L. c. 138, § 69.
Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “A violation of a criminal statute is some evidence of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp. 267 Mass. 501, 516. Baggs v. Hirschfield, 293 Mass. 1, 3. Falvey v. Hamelburg, 347 Mass. 430, 434.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.proposition: Defendant’s disregard of the posted leash rules and his failure to maintain physical control of the Dog constituted a breach of his duty of reasonable care.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s duty to maintain a freight elevator in a reasonably safe condition and whether failing to alter the elevator ceiling or post specific warnings was negligent. It does not involve dogs, leash rules, or any duty to maintain physical control of an animal. The opinion’s discussion of reasonable care is in the context of premises liability and obvious risks from elevator use, so it cannot be authority for breach of duty based on disregarding leash rules for a dog.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.”

Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.raw_text: Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987)
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff’s instinctive reaction—swerving off the path to escape what she reasonably believed to be an imminent attack—was a foreseeable response to Defendant’s negligent failure to control the Dog.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion has nothing to do with dogs, instinctive reactions to imminent attacks, or the foreseeability of a plaintiff’s evasive conduct. It concerns product liability, design defect, and superseding cause in the context of an industrial machine accident. Therefore it does not establish or discuss the legal principle about a plaintiff swerving to avoid a perceived dog attack and cannot be cited for that proposition.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a tortfeasor is liable ‘for the foreseeable intervening conduct of a third party whether that conduct is negligent or not.’ Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 352 n.10 (1983), quoting Wilborg v. Denzell, 359 Mass. 279, 285 (1971).”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Plaintiff’s instinctive reaction—swerving off the path to escape what she reasonably believed to be an imminent attack—was a foreseeable response to Defendant’s negligent failure to control the Dog.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns government immunity and proximate cause in the context of a parole board’s decision and a later shooting by a released prisoner. It does not involve a dog, a defendant’s duty to control an animal, or analysis of an injured plaintiff’s instinctive evasive reaction as a foreseeable consequence of such negligence. The proximate cause discussion focuses on intervening/superseding causes and transfer of responsibility to the INS, not on the foreseeability of a plaintiff’s reaction to an imminent attack by a dog or similar assailant.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events have broken the chain of factual causation or, if not, have otherwise extinguished the element of proximate cause and become a superseding cause of the harm.” (437 Mass. at 320–21).

Doull v. Foster, 487 Mass. 1, 12\u201313.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable where their negligence is a substantial contributing factor in bringing about the plaintiff’s harm, even if other events (such as tripping over a root) also contributed.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The kind of injury Plaintiff suffered—physical injury from evasive action taken to avoid a charging dog—is within the scope of risks that make Defendant’s conduct negligent.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that this type of injury falls within the scope of risks making the defendant’s conduct negligent. Thus, the case (at least as reflected in this excerpt) undermines rather than supports the proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.raw_text: Haddad v. Wal‑Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1), 455 Mass. 91, 99–100 (2009)
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all reasonably foreseeable damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.support_reasoning: The case is a gender‑discrimination and punitive/front‑pay damages decision under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 151B, not a negligence case. It discusses compensatory damages such as emotional distress and lost pay, but in the specific context of employment discrimination and statutory remedies, not the general tort rule that a negligence plaintiff may recover all reasonably foreseeable damages (medical expenses, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, etc.). It therefore does not establish the broad Massachusetts negligence damages principle stated in the proposition.
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded $17,700 in special damages, $125,000 in emotional distress damages, back pay of $95,000, and front pay of $733,307. See Stonehill College v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 549, 567-568, cert. denied sub nom. Wilfert Bros. Realty Co. v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 543 U.S. 979 (2004) (to effectuate remedial purpose of statute, compensatory damages include those which are ‘natural and probable consequences’ of discriminatory act).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
